title: Companies Strive to Retain Employees Who Are Aiming to Leave
text:
Companies Strive to Retain Employees Who Are Aiming to Leave Written by: Chris Metinko 10/26/15 - 11:14 AM EDT Jon Carpenter has worked at a range of venture-backed start-ups and Fortune 500 companies in the tech industry through the last decade. 
Almost all trumpeted the same claim about the importance of retaining their employees — with many falling to do just that. 
“Frankly I think the simplest answer is the right one here — most companies don't genuinely care enough to hear about on-the-job realities of their employees,” said Carpenter, 31, who now works at career services firm Excited for Monday in San Francisco. 
A new survey backs the claim that companies say they want to keep employees — but workers’ attitudes show many would be fine leaving for a better career option. In fact, according to research by talent management firm Saba and WorkplaceTrends.com, 40% say they would leave if a better option became available, and 31% say their skills and talents are not being recognized. “With so many employees looking to leave their current position for one that better suits their needs, it’s clear that employers aren’t taking enough time to get to know individual employee needs, interests and goals,” said Andre Lavoie, CEO of talent management firm ClearCompany. 
Lavoie said a crucial aspect of getting employees to truly devote themselves and their work efforts to the organization is to align those efforts with the company vision. 
“Try assisting employees in setting their work goals each quarter,” he said. “This way, both you and your employees can ensure their individual goals align with the overall goals of the company.” 
The new study showed 49% of human resource leaders agreed retention and leadership development programs were the top priority among talent management goals, and 60% said their companies provide employees with a clear career path for advancement. However, the study also reveals 31% of employees polled said they would share their goals, background talents and what motivates them, but the right questions often are not asked. 1
